Akira Kurosawa

One of Japan's most influential directors

Short Biography

Akira Kurosawa (1910 - 1998) is one of the most well-respected directors of artistic cinema of all time, certaintly in his home country of Japan. He has a long lasting influence in filmmaking and directed about 30 films in a career that lasted 60 years. His crowning achievement is generally considered to be the jidaigeki Seven Samurai (1954) and he wrote a lot of material in that setting. Not a one trick pony, however, he wrote screenplays in a varitey of genres such as drama (Stray Dog, 1949/Ikiru, 1952) and surrealist fantasies (Dreams, 1990.)

“No matter where I go in the world, although I can't speak any foreign language, I don't feel out of place. I think of earth as my home. If everyone thought this way, people might notice just how foolish international friction is and they would put an end to it.” - Akira Kurosawa, Something Like an Autobiography (1982)

Important Films in Cinema

List:

  • Stray Dog (1949)
  • Rashomon (1950)
  • Ikiru (1952)
  • Seven Samurai (1954)
  • Throne of Blood (1957)
  • Hidden Fortress (1958)
  • The Bad Sleep Wall (1960)
  • Yojimbo (1961)
  • Sanjuro (1962)
  • High and Low (1963)
  • Red Beard (1965)
  • Dersu Uzala (1975)
  • Kagemusha (1980)
  • Ran (1985)
  • Dreams (1990)

Visit Wikipedia for a list of more detailed information and filmography!
